I lived in China for two years as a Peace Corps volunteer, so while I'm no expert I have a lot of experience with "dealing with" Chinese people in public. I'm sure just about everything I say here will have already been said since I'm so late so I'll try and keep it simple. 1. Population: there are people everywhere, so pushing and shoving becomes necessary a lot of the time to ensure your place in line, get on a bus or train or to just not get lost in a sea of people 2. The Cultural Revolution led to a lot of intellectuals being jailed or murdered. Spitting on the streets, shoving and talking loudly became signs that you were not a part of the problem, but an average Chinese person and part of the Revolution, which meant these traits became encouraged. 3. Family and friends, your in-group, are all that matters. So when your in public, especially on a vacation, you make sure everyone in your group is having a good time and this of course means that that good time often comes at the expense of most of the people around you who aren't in your group Edit: I'd also add, even though other people have already pointed this out as well, that there modernity and the opportunity to travel abroad is a new development for the vast majority of people, who are only one or two generations removed from thousands of years of being peasants, farmers. It's going to take awhile for these families to become what we would consider "fully modern."

I think a big part of it is, gaming journalists make money in part by hyping games. When they can boast about having info on the next big game, more people will read their articles. But then the game comes out and its just ok, more of the same, just plain bad, etc. Well, this gaming site just spent the last half-year hyping this game, so they can't take it all back and say no actually it's a pretty fun game but nothing you haven't seen before, so they give it a better review than it deserves in order to justify the hype they gave the game prior to its release

Return of the Jedi is the beginning of Lucas taking over the star wars universe and making decisions based more on profit and marketing opportunities rather than quality story telling. Irvin Kershner (director of Episode V) and many other people involved wanted to see han solo die about half way through episode VI, but lucas insisted on having the happy ending with everyone dancing around the campfire to end the series. So with Lucas firmly in control, you get things like the ewoks, luke and leia being siblings, bobba fett dying in the lamest way possible, a climax that is essentially just a repeat of the first film's climax and a happy ending where all the characters basically just have a freeze frame high five. But yeah, some scenes are still great and I'd say overall the film is good, but really doesn't hold up too well under scrutiny or in comparison to the first two

Jurassic World. I went in definitely not expecting a masterpiece. The trailers had all left me pretty cold, but Jurassic Park was such a huge movie for me as a kid and it had been a long time since I got to see a dinosaur movie so basically I went to go see it for the same reasons most people in America did. I found it to be entertaining and not offensively stupid but I still feel like they should have treated the whole thing a little less like an amusement park ride. There wasn't a single tense or suspenseful moment, just 'epic' set piece after set piece, which were all entertaining but left me feeling like I had just seen a very forgettable movie, which Jurassic Park was the opposite of. I think if it had just been a dinosaur movie, and not a film connected to one I still love, I would have been able to accept it as the piece of light entertainment that it was rather than being disappointed in how badly it compares to the original.

WRITING.TITLE: Am I in the minority for liking Terminator 3?
WRITING.TEXT: Since the new Terminator came out, I've seen a lot of discussion about how all the terminator movies since T2 have been bad, and while I agree that the first two are in a league of their own, I enjoyed T3, despite some corny parts, and felt it held its own, especially in comparison to Salvation and Genisys. I've seen a lot of articles/opinions that pointed out T3 as being especially bad, which I found surprising, so I'm curious what other Terminator fans think about that movie in particular.

Yeah, it definitely doesn't come close to T2, but then again, anyone expecting it to probably wasn't aware that Cameron wasn't involved in the third film. I just thought it was a solid action movie that didn't detract from the first two, whereas the second one had a plot that ultimately served no purpose to the overall story and Genisys was just terrible in every way imaginable

Also my favorite part, and it seems Genisys is just ignoring that ending entirely because they refer to Armageddon happening in a different year from 2003. I forget what year specifically, if it was '97 or 2017 or who the hell knows because that movie's story line was garbage, but it definitely wasn't 2003, which is obviously when shit hits the fan according to T3.

The Last of Us. For the story alone, specifically the ending. The game itself was fun, though nothing ground-breaking. But the ending was just so well done. I can't think of another game that has an ambiguous ending like that. Ellie's last line stuck with me for a long time and I still think about it from time to time. It could mean at least a few different things and left you with a totally different perspective on Joel, the character you played (almost) the entire game as and who for the most part came across as a somewhat 2-dimensional character with easily understood motivations, and gave you even greater sympathy for Ellie. The ending really stood out to me compared to most game endings that give a closing shot of the character walking off into the sunset or getting ready to take on the next challenge (read: getting you ready for a sequel) where as The Last of Us's ending forced you to really think about the character and everything you had done.

WRITING.TITLE: Connection between Jackie Brown and Django Unchained (with a bit of extra explanation in Kill Bill 2).
WRITING.TEXT: So maybe this has been pointed out before somewhere, but I've never heard it mentioned. Any fan of Tarantino knows he has little things in his movies that call back to other movies he's made or connects them in some way. Well, the other day I re-watched Jackie Brown, and Sam Jackson is asked what he would do if it turns out Jackie is playing him as well as the cops, and he says (I might be paraphrasing here): "Well, then I'll shoot that nigga in both her knee caps." In Kill Bill 2, Bill explains that getting shot in the knee cap is one of the most painful places to get shot. In Django, Sam Jackson plays the head house slave, which Django explains is as low as it gets for a black person in America (in the eyes of other black people) except for being a free black person who takes part in the slave trade. So what happens to Sam Jackson? He gets shot in both knee caps. Nothing too crazy and there are cooler links between his films, but I thought it was a cool connection between the three films, especially between Sam Jackson's characters in Jackie Brown and Django Unchained.

IV: The Empire has destroyed any remnants of the republic, meaning the Emperor rules the galaxy as a dictator. Luke Skywalker and Han Solo rescue Princess Leia. Obi Wan Kenobi is killed by Darth Vador. The Rebellion (the side Luke Skywalker fights on in the final battle) is able to destroy the Death Star, the Empire's newest, greatest weapon. V: The Empire destroys the Rebel base on Hoth, Luke goes to Degobah to receive training in using the force from Master Yoda, Han Solo and Princess Leia are running from the Empire but are caught by Darth Vader (the Emperor's right hand man) in Cloud City. Han Solo is frozen in carbonite, Luke confronts Vador, finds out Vador is his father, and escapes with Leia. VII: Han and Leia lead an assault on a base on the moon of Endor that destroys the shield protecting the new Death Star the Empire is building. Luke confronts Vador again and just as the Emperor is about to kill Luke, Vador decides to save his son and kill the Emperor. With the shield down, the Rebel assault is able to destroy the Death Star and much of the Empires fleet of star destroyers (really big space ships) and Super star destroyer (Really, really big space ship). Luke escapes from the Death Star (where he fought Vador until the Emperor almost killed him before Vador kills the Emperor) but not before Vador dies from his injuries sustained in fighting luke and killing the Emperor. The Rebels celebrate their victory on Endor. Basically, while the rebels have won, there is still presumably a massive amount of Stormtroopers (soldiers of the Empire) and ships left so while the Empire has lost its leader it stands to reason they wouldn't all just give up. The new Star Wars will probably revolve around the discovery of individuals capable of using the Force and meeting Luke to receive training as well a the remains of the army of the Empire trying to reassert control and continuing to fight the Rebellion while we will also be introduced to new followers of the Dark Side (the Emperor and Darth Vader in the original trilogy) who will fight the new Jedi-in-training in the new trilogy. Hope this wasn't too confusing. Not much is known story-wise about the new trilogy other than that characters from the original trilogy will return and their will be new characters who will be Sith (the Dark Side) and Jedi (at least eventually)

WRITING.TITLE: If you bring a small child movie to a movie theater, please don't think young age is an excuse for rude behavior.
WRITING.TEXT: I saw Star Wars this morning and the five year old next to me talked throughout the entire movie. I asked calmly for him to be quiet early in the film and the father half heartedly told him to quiet down once. After the movie I turned to the father and said he shouldn't bring his son to theaters if he can't be considerate of others to which the father just said repeatedly "He's five." I don't care who you are or how old, talking in theaters distracts the hell out of me and is incredibly inconsiderate. So rant in summary, you're kid's not special, don't be an asshole. Edit: Glad to see this get a strong response. For everyone saying not to complain on reddit but instead complain to theater management, I would like to point out it's possible to do both and that I have no expectation of this post changing many people's minds. But raising a little awareness can't hurt and at the end of the day I just felt like venting after talking to the father obviously went nowhere. Also, for those saying it's an early morning show so I should expect there to be a lot of children and for the children to be loud, I absolutely did expect there to be a lot of kids, and I'm not one to freak out about a kid talking every now and then during a movie. The point of this post is to point out that it's ridiculous for a parent to let their kid do whatever the hell they want in a theater, no matter the movie or showtime. I honestly don't get how any one can disagree with that but I guess I occasionally forget how many inconsiderate people are out there who raise their children to be the same way.

I would maybe say it's ok if I had been at a movie aimed exclusively at little kids, like Minions, but just because a movie (one that is meant for people of all ages) is shown during the daytime, that is not an excuse for piss poor behavior.
Be more compassionate? I was raised to be considerate of others from a young age. Lack of consideration on their part is the problem, not lack of compassion on my part.
I totally fail to see how adoption would have anything to do with this. You must be severely lacking in imagination if this story seems outlandish to you.
Downvotes because it's an issue that a lot of people experience. No one is saying it's a "big deal" but it is an annoyance.

Like I asked someone else on this thread, why is this an unbelievable situation? I'm not an angry person at all, but when I spend $10-$20 to see a movie, I want to be able to enjoy it without distraction.

I considered it, but honestly, I didn't want to make a bigger distraction out of the situation, so I waited for the movie to end. I'm also not looking to kick people out of theaters (if it had gotten really bad, maybe I would have), I just wanted to vent some frustration on reddit over how inconsiderate some people can be.

WRITING.TEXT: Did I say it was bad this joke wouldn't be made today?

I never saw this joke as anything but funny and innocuous as a child. As an adult, I see it through an entirely different lense (though I don't automatically switch to complete outrage like you). I posted it because I think it's interesting how much society's sensibilities have changed in the last decade, and having a joke like this go totally unremarked upon 20 years ago is a great example of that. I should have known though, that without first clarifying that I'm on the "right" side of the issue, I would get preached at in snarky tones on the Internet.

No apologies necessary, and I get where you're coming from completely. If anything, it probably wouldn't have hurt for me to be a little bit more clear when posting this. I will say that while I find this scene in particular to be in bad taste, I don't find it particularly offensive either. The Einhorn plot as a whole, however, I do find problematic, as it definitely reinforced negative preconceptions of transgender people that were held at the time. Maybe this is bad, but despite all that, I'm still an ace Ventura fan; as a child of the 90s, I just can't help myself.

WRITING.TEXT: I think the first one holds up, mainly due to a tight, coherent script and minimal use of CGI, at least in comparison to the next two films. Ultimately, what I think The Matrix has that the next two don't is the strong philosophical undertones that makes it so compelling. There's a reason people still ask if you want the red pill or the blue pill but no one says anything about talking to the architect. The Matrix had easy to understand yet still heady philosophical undertones, while two and three were just a jumbled mess of half-baked ideas that were often there just to kind of pay lip service to the idea that there was some kind of deeper meaning behind the action on screen.

WRITING.TITLE: The Office is a really bad show, even by mainstream sitcom standards.
WRITING.TEXT: I know this is obviously a subjective opinion. I think Friends is good, Big Bang Theory is bad, etc, but usually get it when people disagree with me on which shows they like. But there's something about The Office, at least after the first two seasons, that makes me truly hate the show. It's overly sentimental to the point that characters' actions don't come anywhere close to how humans actually act. Jim and Pam are suppose to be adorable but come across as insufferably smug and often times creepy. Michael and Holly make me cringe to no end. They're suppose to be endearingly awkward but they're actually just completely socially retarded. Every character is "quirky but at the end of the day they're one big happy family" but the quirks are the only defining characteristic. It's like the episode of Sunny that makes fun of popular sitcoms, but that Sunny episode didn't actually go far enough in showing how emotionally manipulative The Office is. I can't stand watching it. It makes me physically uncomfortable. Every moment is suppose to show you how precious all the characters are but it's like it was written by aliens who are close to understanding what makes people attractive or likable but at the end of the day have no understanding of how people actually act in real life.
I think I know my own opinions. I've seen a handful of episodes from later seasons. Haven't watched an entire season after season 4. Edit: uncomfortable, not ill.

WRITING.TITLE: AITA for not texting back friends, romantic interests, significant others?
WRITING.TEXT: I hate texting. I hate how everyone seems to love texting. I've had friendships and relationships end because of this issue. It was a near-constant issue in the longest relationship I've been in, which lasted two years, and that ended partially because of it. I don't see a value in texting. It's not meaningful communication to me. It's not that I don't care how your day was, but texting "How was your day?" "Good. Yours?" just seems so trite and pointless to me. I recently set up Tinder and Bumble profiles and over the past month I matched with a few women and we would agree to go on a date, usually a few days later in the week. But then the next day, the texts would start. "Morning" at 7 am. "How's your day going" in the middle of the day while I'm at work. WTF! I feel like I'm taking crazy pills because why on earth would I, or anyone, want to spend time staring at their phone texting small talk to someone they haven't even met yet? I get that you want to get to know a person at least a little bit before meeting, but it so often goes way beyond that to a degree that I feel is childish. How did any relationship ever last before cell phones? If a couple didn't see each other in person, they'd talk - as in real conversation - over the phone, or - god forbid - go a whole 24 hours without talking. I feel like so many people show real insecurity that I want no part of when they seem to need attention via texts every day. So I ignore the texts. I just don't respond. And then friends think I don't care. Women think I'm not interested. I think they're childish. But maybe ITA.

Yeah, I def did make it sound like that but I do communicate to my friends and significant other that it's simply not something I'm comfortable doing, and that when they repeatedly text me I feel forced into communicating in a way that I do not derive any meaning from and struggle with. I really struggle with the messaging. So many people take it as me saying I don't care. But that's not it! I just don't feel that I can meaningfully engage through that particular mode of communication. It's especially tough in the dating app situation. How do you explain to someone you just met that if they text you small talk, you're simply not going to respond, without them taking offense? I have no idea. If there's a way, I'd love to know it.

Yeah, I definitely expected to have to, as you said, wade through some bs, but what's frustrating me now is a couple women I met I really liked! But then almost right away, from a communication standpoint, it became clear it wasn't going to work. If you need constant affirmation in the form of texts every day, I'm simply not the guy for you. But it's increasingly seeming like that's the vast majority of people so I'm frustrated that my stance on this topic, which I think is a reasonable one, puts me at odds with so many people.
Lol, this comment didn't give me hope that I can find common ground with most people on this but it definitely made me laugh
Thank you :) felt good to hear this haha

WRITING.TITLE: The Golden Age of television is dead.
WRITING.TEXT: There isn't a single show left on air capable of bringing people together for a national conversation, like shows like Breaking Bad and GoT did. We've gone through dozens of iterations of the "anti-hero with a personal secret/problem" story line that was already perfected the first time with the show that issued in the Golden Age, The Sopranos, so we moved on to epic-scale storytelling or niche stories. Now shows are either so focused on being the next big thing that they focus on epic story lines that will start a hashtag trend, a la Westworld, which as far as I can tell most people already stopped caring about, or focus on catching a niche market, a la Divorce or, ugh, Frankenstein's Monster's Monster, Frankenstein. There are hundreds of pretty good shows, and every now and then almost-great one-season shows like The Terror or Chernobyl. But the age of truly great television, shows that captured an era or brought about a new trend in story telling, is gone. Maybe, probably, not for good, but with the proliferation of streaming services and over saturation of shows based on previous popular shows and trends, it's safe to say that the quality of shows has gone down considerably and likely won't return until networks stop chasing the next big thing and go back to just letting writers tell their own stories no matter what they think might make for the next big hit.

I would maybe move it up a little later, say around 2015. Breaking Bad didn't finish until 2013, Mad Men until 2015. I'd say right around then is also when GoT officially started going off the tracks, so you could put the Golden Age at beginning of The Sopranos, 1999 to 2015.

WRITING.TITLE: TILL the 1994 movie Baby's Day Out was remade in India and titled James Bond

WRITING.TEXT: Very much agree. The humor in particular really rubs me the wrong way. It's like they write a basic script and some kind of algorithm that determines where humor should be writes "insert joke here" and then a team of writers worked tirelessly to come up with the most easily understood, unoffensive joke possible to place there. But not just the humor, everything in the films seems market tested to the nth degree to ensure nothing goes over anyones head. I never get a sense of a singular creative vision or drive to try something new behind the films. They're all fine, and they all mostly bore me and I can't wait to not watch the movie again once it's over.
